http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1571017/spring3-hibernate3-testng-some-tests-give-lazyinitializationexception-some-don

Cedric


On Thu, Dec 31, 2009 at 9:54 AM, Berin <berin.loritsch@...> wrote:

>
>
> I'm trying to test some behavior using Hibernate/Spring transactional
> support, but I'm running into a particular snag. By default, the transaction
> manager is bound to the current thread.
>
> Problem is that with tests that have the "timeout" attribute specified,
> JUnit creates a new thread to ensure the timeout is enforced. For example:
>
> @Test(timeout=100)
> public void makeSureActionHappenedRecently() {
> AuditLog.get().logEvent(EventType.TestEvent, "Foo");
>
> Collection<AuditEvent> log =
> AuditLog.get().findEventsFor(EventType.TestEvent);
>
> assertNotEmpty(log);
> // make sure timestamp is within X ms
> assertRecent(100, log.iterator().next().getTimestamp());
> }
>
> This works without the (timeout=100) qualification because Hibernate is set
> up in the @BeforeClass.
>
> Technically I could put the set up in an @Before method, but that becomes
> rather expensive (setting up Spring, Hibernate, connecting to database).
>
> Any clues on how to make this work?
>
>
>
